author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: What We Know About the Death Toll in Israel From the Hamas-Led Attacks
description: Israel’s ability to give an accurate count of how many died in Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack has been complicated by corpses that were mutilated and identifying foreign workers killed in the attacks.
content: Israel revised its official estimated death toll of the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks, lowering the number to about 1,200 people, down from the more than 1,400 initially cited, a spokesman for the country’s Foreign Ministry said on Friday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Kelly Johnson Embodies the Hard-Line Views She Shares With the Speaker
description: The wife of Mike Johnson, the new speaker, has rallied opposition to abortion rights and used her pastoral counseling business to condemn homosexuality.
content: As Speaker Mike Johnson likes to tell it, it was love at first sight when he first met Kelly Lary, the sunny, blonde former Kappa Delta who caught his eye in a red dress at the wedding of a mutual friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: How Ukraine, With No Warships, Is Thwarting Russia’s Navy
description: The commander of Ukraine’s Navy said in a rare interview that the Russian naval blockade of Odesa had been broken. He also described how the war is transforming naval tactics.
content: In a small, hidden office in the port city of Odesa, the commander of the Ukrainian Navy keeps two trophies representing successes in the Black Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost and Abigail Varney
title: The Corner Lot Where All the World’s Vegemite Comes From
description: First concocted a century ago, the spread is widely adored by Australians — and loathed by almost everyone else.
content: Just off Australia’s largest container port lies a sickle-shaped neighborhood with a scent so distinctive that passing taxi drivers will sometimes roll down their windows for a whiff of the rich and unmistakably beery aroma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A. Walter Dorn
title: Measuring Israel by the Just-War Yardstick
description: The Netanyahu government falls short on most benchmarks of whether its actions in Gaza meet the standard.
content: Israel’s response to the horrifying Hamas attack on Oct. 7 has caused widespread protest among its critics and soul-searching among some of its supporters. The deaths of thousands of Palestinian civilians in a ferocious bombing campaign and an increasingly intense ground war in the Gaza Strip cry out for a careful examination of the moral basis for Israel’s actions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: New Gene Editing Treatment Cuts Dangerous Cholesterol in Small Study
description: The trial involved only 10 patients, but it suggests cholesterol can be permanently reduced with a single treatment for patients at risk of heart disease.
content: The handful of patients had severe heart disease that had caused chest pain and heart attacks. After trying available cholesterol-lowering medications, they could not get their cholesterol as low as cardiologists recommended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Bhadra Sharma and Claire Fu
title: Nepal Is Investigating New Airport Made by China
description: After a Times article about the cost and quality of Pokhara airport, which Chinese state-owned firms financed and built, Nepal’s anti-corruption agency said it was looking into the project.
content: As developing countries weigh the consequences of borrowing heavily from China for major infrastructure projects, anti-corruption officials in Nepal have begun an investigation into a flagship airport financed and built by Chinese state-owned companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Emily Rhyne
title: Army Ammunition Plant Is Tied to Mass Shootings Across the U.S.
description: The site was built for the military, but commercial sales are booming with little public accountability. Rounds have been bought by murderers, antigovernment groups and others.
content: Christopher Hixon, a 27-year veteran of the Navy who served in the Persian Gulf, trained with government ammunition that typically had a distinctive “LC” marking on its brass casings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: 30 Horses Die in Arson Fire at Upstate Racetrack
description: Firefighters and horse owners rushed to the scene after the blaze started in a barn, but none of the horses could be saved.
content: Dozens of racehorses were killed last week when an arsonist set fire to a barn in upstate New York, leaving their owners devastated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: 5 U.S. Special Operations Troops Killed in Helicopter Crash in Mediterranean
description: The troops were on a refueling training mission when the aircraft crashed off the coast of Cyprus. The episode, which Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said was an accident, is under investigation.
content: Five members of the U.S. Army Special Operations forces have died in a helicopter crash in the eastern Mediterranean Sea, American officials said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: From Elvis to Elopements, the Evolution of the Las Vegas Wedding
description: After 70 years as the “Wedding Capital of the World,” the glittering city that attracts thousands of couples seeking unconventional nuptials has grown beyond the drive-through wedding.
content: Las Vegas has long been a stage where reality dissolves into fantasy. In the heart of the desert — a place where the Eiffel Tower, Egyptian pyramids and medieval castles all beam on one glamorous strip — the entertainment is virtually unlimited. It’s no wonder, then, that a city built on the promise of pleasure and escape has remained a popular destination for weddings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Perfect Lasagna
description: Serve for Sunday supper now, or parbake and freeze to feed the family later.
content: Good morning. At last, it’s oven weather where I stay. I set the thermostat low, put on a sweater under my apron and get to work: a Guinness pie, say, or a braised leg of lamb? Better yet, a perfect lasagna (above).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Proposal to Fix Housing That Already Inspired a Cult
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 12, 2023
content: “This isn’t any deep philosophical movement. I’m trying to cut taxes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: The Occupied West Bank: Divided by Faith, United by Fear
description: As bloodshed surges around them, an Israeli settler and a Palestinian tour guide search for answers — and a shred of hope.
content: As Moish Feiglin pulls up to his settlement in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, he points to an eight-foot-tall concrete slab blocking the middle of the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Morris
title: For Joan Armatrading, Classical Music Is Just Another Genre
description: The pioneering singer-songwriter is unveiling her first classical composition, Symphony No. 1, this month.
content: Last year, Chi-chi Nwanoku, the founder and artistic director of the Chineke! Orchestra, received an email out of the blue from the singer-songwriter Joan Armatrading. She, the message said, had finished composing her first classical composition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: The ‘Georgists’ Are Out There, and They Want to Tax Your Land
description: Amid a crisis in affordable housing, the century-old ideas of Henry George have gained a new currency.
content: When Mayor Mike Duggan talks about his accomplishments in Detroit, the list is both impressive and sad. He had the streetlights turned back on, and reopened closed parks. In the decade since he took office, the city has demolished some 25,000 blighted homes whose rusty debris and incubation of crime drag down neighborhoods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg, Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman and Vivian Yee
title: Israeli Forces Near a Struggling Hospital They Say Covers a Hamas Complex
description: Israeli officials say that Hamas has built a complex under Al Shifa, a major Gaza hospital. Hamas denies it is operating from beneath the hospital, whose patients face dire conditions amid power cuts.
content: With Israel consolidating its hold on northern Gaza, its forces are closing in on a sprawling medical center that for Israelis and Palestinians alike has emerged as a symbol of the other side’s inhumanity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Take a Break
description: Benjamin Fink makes a convincing puzzle in his New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Callaghan O'Hare
title: In Texas, Vietnamese American Shrimpers Must Forge a New Path Again
description: They overcame the trauma of war, language barriers and prejudice to become successful shrimpers. But the decline of the industry in America is forcing them to consider other options.
content: The sun was still rising when Vinh Nguyen hauled in his first catch of the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Marvel Flounders at the Box Office With ‘The Marvels’
description: “The Marvels” cost about $300 million to make and market and arrived to $47 million in domestic sales.
content: The once-superheroic Marvel Studios is now merely mortal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Inside the Army Factory That Makes AR-15 Ammunition: 4 Takeaways
description: Commercial rounds are being manufactured on government property. Some have been used in violent crimes, including mass shootings.
content: The Lake City Army Ammunition Plant, built during World War II, has long been operated for the federal government by private contractors. Over the past decade, a New York Times investigation found, the site has increasingly produced rounds for the commercial market as military demand has diminished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: In Veterans Day Speech, Trump Promises to ‘Root Out’ the Left
description: The former president said that threats from abroad were less concerning than liberal “threats from within” and that he was a “very proud election denier.”
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, on a day set aside to celebrate those who have defended the United States in uniform, promised to honor veterans in part by assailing what he portrayed as America’s greatest foe: the political left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Hikers Rescued After Following Nonexistent Trail on Google Maps
description: A Canadian search-and-rescue group said it had conducted two missions recently after hikers “may have sought to follow” a nonexistent trail on Google Maps.
content: A search-and-rescue group in British Columbia advised hikers to use a paper map and compass instead of street map programs after it said two hikers had been rescued by helicopter after likely following a trail that did not exist but that appeared on Google Maps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Preet Bharara
title: Case Closed?
description: Every day prosecutors choose to keep former targets in the dark, never telling them that the case against them is dead.
content: Prosecutors formally advised lawyers for former Vice President Mike Pence this past June that he would not be charged for retaining classified materials after leaving office. I expect that the special counsel Robert Hur will similarly soon announce that President Biden will not face charges for his own handling of classified documents. The merits of those determinations, no less than the one to indict Donald Trump for hoarding such documents in Mar-a-Lago’s bathrooms and ballrooms, are properly debated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Liz Alderman
title: Over 100,000 March in France Against Antisemitism
description: The demonstrations in Paris and other cities came amid a rise in tensions in France over the Gaza war and a surge in antisemitic incidents.
content: More than 100,000 demonstrators in Paris and cities across France took to the streets on Sunday to show their solidarity with the country’s Jews and to deplore antisemitic acts that have multiplied across the nation since Hamas’s attack on Israel on Oct. 7.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: Is Remote Work the Answer to Women’s Prayers, or a New ‘Mommy Track’?
description: Post-pandemic work-from-home norms allowed more women to stay in the work force than ever before. Remote work could also make it harder to get ahead.
content: In 1989, the legal scholar Joan C. Williams published a theory for why professional women were “opting out” of their careers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Peter Nygard, Former Fashion Mogul, Convicted of Sexual Assault
description: The verdict in Toronto concludes the first of Mr. Nygard’s criminal trials in Canada. The 82-year-old also faces charges in the United States.
content: A Toronto jury on Sunday found Peter Nygard, the high-profile executive behind a fallen fashion empire, guilty of four counts of sexual assault after just over three days of deliberation at the end of a six-week trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Should Your Ex-Boss Get a Say in Your New Job? Wall Street Says Yes.
description: Legislation in New York that would outlaw noncompete agreements, a staple at big banks, has led to frenzied lobbying to persuade Gov. Kathy Hochul to kill the effort.
content: For high-powered Wall Street and banking executives, one of the hallmarks of the job comes into play only at the end: a signed noncompete agreement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 13, 2023
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Offers Up Little Debate
description: Timothée Chalamet hosted an episode that presented former President Trump as an aggrieved forerunner. The musical guest was boygenius.
content: Come on, you didn’t really think that “Saturday Night Live” would begin this weekend with a parody of the third Republican presidential debate, did you?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman, Jeanna Smialek and Hilary Swift
title: Vermont May Be the Face of a Long-Term U.S. Labor Shortage
description: Employers are pulling out all the stops to attract workers as the state’s population grows older, offering a likely glimpse of the country’s future.
content: At Lake Champlain Chocolates, the owners take shifts stacking boxes in the warehouse. At Burlington Bagel Bakery, a sign in the window advertises wages starting at $25 an hour. Central Vermont Medical Center is training administrative employees to become nurses. Cabot Creamery is bringing workers from out of state to package its signature blocks of Cheddar cheese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: At Salon Art + Design, Gold Bracelets and Lipstick-Red Monochromes
description: The 12th edition of the fair, dedicated to fine and decorative arts, offers a beguiling mix of paintings, jewelry and modern Brazilian design.
content: This year’s Salon Art + Design, the 12th edition of a fair dedicated to fine and decorative arts, transforms the Park Avenue Armory into a fabulous and eccentric collector’s house. Open through Monday, it brings together works on paper by the artist Robert Mangold (Zeit Contemporary Art) and wooden sculpture by Louise Nevelson (Galerie Gmurzynska) alongside rare books (Potterton Books), chunky gold Tiffany bracelets (DK Farnum) and a shiny, surreal, curiously tooth-like chair made of solid bronze by Voukenas Petrides (Fumi Gallery).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The New Republican Party Isn’t Ready for the Post-Roe World
description: With leaders like Trump, the pro-life movement can’t prevail.
content: Ohio is not a swing state, not any longer. Donald Trump won it by eight points, twice. It has a Republican governor, and while its senators are split between the parties, its U.S. House delegation is made up of 10 Republicans and five Democrats. And yet Ohio just passed an abortion-rights referendum by a margin of more than 13 points.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Alessandro Marazzi Sassoon and Colbi Edmonds
title: A Mayor’s Suicide Leaves an Alabama City Seeking Answers
description: The mayor fatally shot himself after a news site published a photo of him in makeup and said he had written erotic fiction and posts using names and photos of local residents, including a minor.
content: F.L. Copeland Jr., a Baptist pastor and grocery store owner known as Bubba, once told a colleague that being mayor of Smiths Station, Ala., reminded him of a real-life version of the popular Sims computer game: building a community, then dealing with the complexities and crises that emerged along the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Monday Briefing: Conditions Worsen in Gazan Hospitals
description: Plus Vegemite’s 100th birthday.
content: The Palestinian Red Crescent said yesterday that Al-Quds Hospital in Gaza City was “no longer operational,” as power outages and shortages of fuel continued to wreak havoc on Gaza’s health facilities. The Gazan aid group said that more than 14,000 displaced people had been sheltering there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner, Aaron Boxerman and Thomas Fuller
title: Netanyahu Sees No Near-Term Role for Palestinian Authority in a Postwar Gaza
description: Differing from the U.S. view, the Israeli prime minister also said Israel must retain security control over Gaza so it can be “demilitarized” and “de-radicalized.”
content: JERUSALEM — Even as Israeli tanks and ground troops continued to battle Hamas militants in Gaza, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday outlined a postwar vision for the territory, one that he said would not involve the Palestinian Authority in its current form.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Toxic Air Is No Reason to Stay Inside for Delhi’s Joggers and Yoga Fans
description: In India’s capital, skipping exercise and the social routines that often come with it is seen as worse than going out and breathing poison.
content: A few steps into his early-morning run, Purushottam Sahu struggled to breathe. He started coughing. He felt as if he might vomit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Hundreds of Thousands Protest Spanish Prime Minister’s Deal With Separatists
description: The deal, which grants amnesty to secessionists, is meant to give Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez enough support to form a coalition to stay in power.
content: Hundreds of thousands of incensed Spaniards responded to the call of conservative parties on Sunday and packed squares across the country to protest a deal that Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez, a Socialist, reached with secessionists to grant them amnesties in exchange for the political support required for him to retain power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle, Ella Koeze and Brian X. Chen
title: You Paid $1,000 for an iPhone, but Apple Still Controls It
description: The company codes its devices with software that complicates repairs by triggering safety warnings and malfunctions.
content: For a decade, it was easy to get help repairing an iPhone. Cracked screens could be replaced in minutes, and broken cameras could be exchanged without a hitch.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 12, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 12, 2023.
content: An article on Page 14 this weekend about the U.S. Space Force misspelled the surname of a member of the U.S. Space Force. He is Lt. Col. Galen Thorp, not Thorpe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan and Vik Jolly
title: Major Freeway Near Downtown Los Angeles Is Closed Indefinitely After Fire
description: All lanes on a part of Interstate 10 remained closed a day after two nearby storage yards were engulfed in flames. Officials are investigating the cause of the fire.
content: Drivers in Los Angeles who use one of the busiest freeways in the area will need to change their travel plans for an indefinite period of time as authorities assess the damage from a fire early Saturday that shut down part of an interstate downtown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: What Happens When Palestinians Tell Their Stories Directly to the World?
description: Far too many civilians are dying in Gaza, but Palestinian voices are being heard like never before.
content: After the Israeli military killed his older brother in an airstrike in Gaza in 2014, Ahmed Alnaouq says, he almost lost his will to live. “I sank into a deep depression,” he told me in a recent phone call. But an American friend convinced him to write about his brother and channel his grief into something productive. Together, they founded We Are Not Numbers, a project that trains young writers in Gaza and publishes their personal essays in English.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Carries Out Another Round of Airstrikes on Targets Tied to Iran
description: Airstrikes hit two facilities in eastern Syria, most likely killing or injuring Iran-backed militia personnel. The U.S. has blamed such groups for recent attacks against American troops.
content: The United States conducted a new round of airstrikes against facilities used by Iran and its proxies in eastern Syria late Sunday in retaliation for a spate of recent attacks against American troops, Pentagon officials said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius, Nate Schweber and Mihir Zaveri
title: 3 Dead, 14 Injured in Brooklyn House Fire
description: All three floors of a rowhouse in Crown Heights were on fire when firefighters arrived. At least one firefighter was injured.
content: A fire in a Brooklyn rowhouse early Sunday morning left three people dead and 14 people injured, police officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrea Barrett
title: A Swift, Opinionated Portrait of Willa Cather (She Would Have Approved)
description: “Chasing Bright Medusas,” a new biography by Benjamin Taylor, aims not to uncover new facts but to provide a concise introduction to the novelist.
content: During the difficult months of 2020, a writer friend and I decided to read Willa Cather’s fiction together. What a good antidote to despair that was. Much of it was rereading, but I’d missed some stories and novels, and I’d never read them sequentially or with a clear sense of Cather’s life. That spring I also delved into several of the biographies, which taught me something about how such books can vary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Murray and Kate Shaw
title: The Conservative Supreme Court Vision That Means Inequality for Women
description: The Roberts court’s commitment to history and tradition leads to decisions that reflect a constitutional order made with men in mind.
content: The Supreme Court last week heard oral arguments in United States v. Rahimi, a challenge to a federal law that takes guns away from people subject to domestic violence restraining orders. From the moment the court agreed to hear the case, advocates hoped it would provide an opportunity for the court to limit the sweep of last year’s blockbuster decision expanding gun rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Desiree Ibekwe
title: Barbra Streisand, in Her Own Words
description: The singer has released a 1,000-page memoir. Its heart is a story of perseverance.
content: This year’s memoirs have kept ravenous consumers of celebrity culture well fed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: In Israel, Christie Says Trump Ducked Mideast Progress and Fueled Bigotry
description: The former New Jersey governor and chief G.O.P. antagonist to the former president cited Mr. Trump’s rhetoric of intolerance and faulted him for a lack of ambition on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
content: Chris Christie, the former governor of New Jersey who is challenging Donald J. Trump for the Republican presidential nomination, said Mr. Trump’s rhetoric of intolerance — as evident today as it was during his presidency — had fueled the surge of bigotry confronting Jews and Muslims after Hamas’s brutal Oct. 7 attack on Israel and the fierce Israeli response in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Dana Rubinstein and Michael Rothfeld
title: F.B.I. Examining Whether Adams Cleared Red Tape for Turkish Government
description: After winning the 2021 Democratic mayoral primary, Eric Adams successfully pressed city officials to allow the opening of a Manhattan high-rise housing the Turkish Consulate General.
content: Federal authorities are investigating whether Mayor Eric Adams, weeks before his election two years ago, pressured New York Fire Department officials to sign off on the Turkish government’s new high-rise consulate in Manhattan despite safety concerns with the building, three people with knowledge of the matter said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Her Livelihood? Hunting Pythons in the Dead of Night.
description: Amy Siewe teaches people how to find and euthanize invasive Burmese pythons, which have been so successful at adapting to Florida that they appear here to stay.
content: An unexpected chill can fall over the Florida Everglades late at night. Stars speckle the sky. Frogs croak and croak, their mating calls echoing in the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Tingley
title: The Bodily Indignities of the Space Life
description: The race is on to put hotels in space and neighborhoods on the moon. Here’s some of what we know about how Earthlings fare beyond the safety of our home world.
content: As an incubator of life, Earth has a lot going for it, something we often fail to appreciate fully from within its nurturing bounds. Merely sending probes and rovers to the moon and Mars won’t do. For various reasons — adventure! apocalypse! commerce! — we insist upon taking our corporeal selves off-world too. Multiple private companies have announced plans to put hotels in space soon. NASA is aiming to 3-D-print lunar neighborhoods within a couple of decades. And while it will probably take longer than that to build and populate an outpost on Mars, preparations are being made: This summer, four NASA crew members began a 378-day stay in simulated Martian housing at the Johnson Space Center in Houston.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Driver Stayed in the Car With the Radio On and the Window Open’
description: A sidewalk singalong, an eventful pedicab ride and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Is the Democratic Base Eroding?
description: Readers react to a column by Pamela Paul criticizing the party’s direction. Also: Inequality and test scores; WIC funding.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Angier
title: Why Vultures Might Just Be the Smartest Birds Above the Block
description: The birds are widely reviled for their carrion-eating ways. But an evolutionary history of scavenging has forged a creative, cunning and wide-ranging mind.
content: The two lappet-faced vultures had been together for just a few months, yet the massive birds, with their watchful, featherless gargoyle faces and their dark mottled body plumage so plush it looks like fur, had already mastered the avian version of monkey-see-monkey-do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Orlando Mayorquin
title: Son of Former Hollywood Agent Is Charged in Woman’s Murder
description: The police believe the victim is the wife of the suspect, Samuel Haskell, the son of a veteran talent agent and film producer. Mr. Haskell’s in-laws were missing as of Saturday.
content: The son of a once prominent Hollywood agent and executive has been charged in the murder of a woman investigators believe to be his wife and whose remains were found bagged inside a dumpster in Los Angeles this week, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: When Ruthless Cultural Elitism Is Exactly the Job
description: “It tends to be true that the best publishers are people who read books,” says literary kingmaker Andrew Wylie.
content: “It tends to be true that the best publishers are people who read books,” says literary kingmaker Andrew Wylie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Ivan Penn
title: U.S. Bets on Small Nuclear Reactors to Help Fix a Huge Climate Problem
description: The dream of reviving nuclear power in the U.S. rests on a new generation of smaller reactors meant to be easier to build. But major obstacles loom.
content: The dream of reviving nuclear power in the U.S. rests on a new generation of smaller reactors meant to be easier to build. But major obstacles loom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Axel Boada
title: About 300,000 People Participate in Pro-Palestinian March in London
description: Demonstrators marched in support of Palestine and demanded a cease-fire in Gaza in one of Britain’s largest protests in recent years.
content: Demonstrators marched in support of Palestine and demanded a cease-fire in Gaza in one of Britain’s largest protests in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times
